Research on human-digital twin partnerships highlights several key areas for long-term investigation. Studies emphasize the importance of maintaining user engagement over extended periods (Bickmore et al., 2010) and adapting to users' needs and preferences (Lim et al., 2023). The development of AI-generated digital twins for personalized healthcare shows promise but requires addressing technological, regulatory, and trust challenges (Łukaniszyn et al., 2024). Longitudinal studies are crucial for understanding the evolution of human-robot interactions and informing design improvements (Lim et al., 2023; Greeff et al., 2018). Research also focuses on cognitive state monitoring and system adaptation in human-autonomy teaming (Rauffet, 2022). The need for long-term, decentralized field research networks to study human behavior and culture in ecological contexts is emphasized (Mcelreath, 2017). Additionally, advancing conceptual clarity, proper scoping, and methodological rigor in digital platform research is recommended (Reuver et al., 2018).
